item.title: The Frutado AG
General Information
item.dc:description:
General Information

This chapter introduces the Frutado AG and explains the company structure.
In addition the companys' history is described.

Duration of this Lesson: 5min.

item.title: Basic Data
item.dc:description:
Basic Data

This chapter gives an overview of the data, which is needed to model the Frutado AG. The specific data is compiled in a single document, which can be viewed here.

Duration of this Lesson: 7min.

item.title: Planning Concept
item.dc:description:
Planning Concept

This chapter decribes the ideal planning concept of the Frutado AG and the modifications needed to implement the case study.

Duration of this Lesson: 10min.

The Frutado AG

This chapter deals with the Frutado AG as a company. After a general introduction, all relevant data for the SAP APO is described and the planning concept is presented.

item.title: Advanced Planning Systems
Structure
item.dc:description:
Structure

This chapter shows the structure of Advanced Planning Systems.

Duration of this Lesson: 5min.

item.title: Fundamentals
item.dc:description:
Fundamentals

This chapter shows the fundamentals of Advanced Planning Systems.

Duration of this Lesson: 4min.

item.title: The SAP APO
item.dc:description:
The SAP APO

This chapter gives an overview of the modules of the SAP APO.

Duration of this Lesson: 3min.

Advanced Planning Systems

This chapter deals with the structure and the fundamentals of Advanced Planning Systems going into greater detail with the SAP APO.

item.title: Tutorial
Demand Planning
Transferring Data from an InfoCube to a Planning Version
Transferring Data from an InfoCube to a Planning Version Demo
Transferring Data from an InfoCube to a Planning Version Practice

item.dc:description:
Transferring Data from an InfoCube to a Planning Version 

To start the planning process it is necessary to upload the variable data from an
InfoCubeInfoCube

An object that can function as both a data target and an InfoProvider.

. This InfoCube (FRU_ICUBE) has been created using the data warehousing workbench. The key figures which exist in the planning area have been assigned to it. The actual data upload to the InfoCube has already taken place so that the data only needs to be transferred to the planning version (FRU_PV_DP) of the Frutado AG.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 7 min.

item.title: Define Planning Book
item.dc:description:
Define Planning Book 

In order to provide the demand planner with only the data that concerns his module a planning book can be created. This planning book is directly linked to a specific planning area. A selection of key figures – which belong to the planning area – can be specified to use in the planning book.

The planning book of the Frutado AG (FRU_DP_PLAN) contains all key figures of the planning area. The characteristics of the planning area can also be assigned to the planning book. Similarly all characteristics of the Frutado AG are transferred to the planning book.

By assigning different data views to one planning book it is possible to have multiple graphical user interfaces. The data view defines how the interactive planning interface will appear and specifies the planning horizon.

Only one data view is needed for the Frutado AG (FRU_DP_VIEW_DP). To complete the planning book, key figures must be assigned to the data view which has just been created. Again the data view of the Frutado AG contains all key figures.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 10 min.

item.title: Create Forecast Profiles
item.dc:description:
Create Forecast Profiles 

The master forecast profile determines important features of the demand planning process:
the time frame in which the historical data is used, the planning horizon, the time frame and the forecast profile.

The APO has two different forecast profiles to choose from – the univariate forecast and the multiple linear regression. In addition both forecast profiles can be combined by defining an emphasis factor. A univariate forecast is only based upon one time factor while multiple linear regression uses several influencing factors.

As the Frutado AG does not use multiple linear regression profiles, these will not be explained further. In the univariate profile template the user has a choice of multiple forecast strategies to select from. The Frutado AG uses two different forecast profiles.
The forecast profile for products with a steady demand is called FRU_CONST_DP, with exponential smoothing being the according forecast strategy. Seasonal linear regression is used as the forecast strategy for products with a seasonal demand (FRU_SEAS_DP).

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 5 min.

item.title: Calculate Proportional Factors
item.dc:description:
Calculate Proportional Factors 

The supply chain department of the Frutado AG has analyzed the historical data and has come to the conclusion that creating forecasts on the basis of aggregated products would be a good solution. The allocation of products to the aggregated groups takes place in the next chapter “Create Product Aggregates”.

This chapter deals with the calculation of proportional factors which are used when the aggregated groups are split up into their basic form. The base of this calculation is a key figure – in case of the Frutado AG the historical data. The DP-module analyzes the ratio of the accumulated past demand of a product and compares it to the accumulated past demand of the according aggregated group. This method implies that the constitution of the single products in an aggregated group stays the same over the complete period of time.

A time based disaggregation is not needed with the Frutado AG. The demand figures which are needed by the subsequent modules are created in the time granularity needed.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 3 min.

item.title: Create Aggregate Groups
item.dc:description:
Create Aggregate Groups 

The supply chain department of the Frutado AG has analyzed the historical data and has come to the conclusion that some products should be forecasted in aggregated groups. This is done by the demand planner who has the possibility to create different selections on which the demand forecasts are based. In order to disaggregate the results the proportional factors calculated in the last lesson are used.

The Frutado AG would like to use five different product groups, which are additionally aggregated, for all distribution centers. These groups are especially suited to minimize the observed forecast errors. Three of the aggregated groups consist of products with a steady demand while the other two consist of products with seasonal demand. In order to create the different groups it is necessary to enter the selection criteria of each group.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 7 min.

item.title: Calculate Forecasts
item.dc:description:
Calculate Forecasts 

Everything is now set for the demand forecasts to be calculated. The profiles for the different aggregate groups have been created and the proportional factors have been calculated.
In this lesson only the basis of the interactive demand planning is shown. For more information please view the in-depth stream of the demand planning module.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 15 min.

item.title: Release of the Demand Plan to Supply Network Planning
Release of the Demand Plan to Supply Network Planning Demo
Release of the Demand Plan to Supply Network Planning Practice

item.dc:description:
Release of the Demand Plan to Supply Network Planning 

The values of the demand plan are stored in anonymous liveCache time series objects. When releasing the demand plan these time series objects are transformed into liveCache orders .This leads to the forecasted demand being apparent for the Supply Network Planning, the PP/DS and the Deployment module. All following modules must try to satisfy the forecasted demand by creating feasible plans.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 3 min.

item.title: In-Depth Stream
Judgemental Forecasting
Promotion Planning
Define the Promotion level for the planning area
Define the Promotion level for the planning area Demo
Define the Promotion level for the planning area Practice

item.dc:description:
Define the Promotion level for the planning area 

The objective of this lesson is to define the Promotion Level. By defining the Promotion Level you decide, for instance, if you want to plan promotions for products or locations.
The Frutado AG plans to give a 10%-Discount on the Aggregated Product Group "FRU_SEAS1_DP_PROMO". That means that we have to choose Product as the Promotion Level.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 min.

item.title: Create a Promotion Base
item.dc:description:
Create a Promotion Base 

You can use the Promotion Base to define the basis for several promotions. In the Promotion Base you specify the characteristics (at least one, the promotion level) that you want to use for Promotion Planning. You have to assign a key figure to each Promotion Base. Every Promotion Base must have a different promotion key figure. This limits the number of possible Promotion Bases.
A promotion base is defined for a limited period. Two promotion bases can have the same or overlapping dates and the same characteristic combinations in the same planning area.

When you create a new promotion you can assign it to a Promotion Base. The system automatically loads the relevant information. In particular it determines the characteristics in the promotion base and the promotion key figure. In promotion planning you cannot assign values to characteristics that have not been included in the promotion base.

In this lesson a Promotion Base is create for future Promotions of the Frutado AG.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 min.

item.title: Edit the Planning Data for the Promotion
Edit the Planning Data for the Promotion Demo
Edit the Planning Data for the Promotion Practice

item.dc:description:
Edit the Planning Data for the Promotion 

After you have created a promotion you have to assign objects to it.
There are two ways to assign objects.
With the multiple assignment you can assign multiple objects at once. The promotion level is automatically included. As you are working with a Promotion Base, the characteristics in the Promotion Base are copied to the promotion automatically. You can remove any characteristics but you can only add those characteristics that are contained in the promotion base.
With the single assignment you can assign characteristics together with values at individual characteristic level.
In the following example, use the multiple assignment to assign the aggregated product group "FRU_SEAS1_DP_PROMO".
After you have assigned the object the grid shows the single products of the group.
Now enter the expected influence of the current promotion. It is expected that the discount of 10% has a demand-increasing-impact of 5% on the whole aggregated group during the 8 weeks.
The system calculates the absolute numbers.
To take these expectations into account in Interactive Planning, you have to change the status of the promotion to "Planned in the future".

Now you can check the results in Interactive Planning.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 min.

item.title: Create a Promotion
item.dc:description:
Create a Promotion 

The objective of this lesson is to create a new Promotion ("Discount for FRU_SEAS1_DP_PROMO"). This Promotion will take place in the beginning of the year 2009 (Start: January 5th, 2009) and will last for eight weeks. It is expected that due to the promotion, the demand for the Aggregated Product Grup FRU_SEAS1_DP_PROMO will increase about 5%.

You can create new Promotions In the Promotion Planning screen.

As you use a Promotion Base you only has to fill in the name, the description, the type and the period of the promotion.

You create the Promotion by saving these information. The system immediately generates a grid for the promotion. From then on the promotion is available in the system, but not yet active.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 5 min.

Promotion Planning 

In this chapter you see how to set the stage for Promotion Planning, how to create a Promotion Base, how to create a Promotion and how to edit the Planning Data for the Promition and finally how to take the Promotion Planning results into account in the Interactive Planning.

Judgemental Forecasting 

The objective of this lesson is to show how to plan promotions in SAP APO DP.

Until now the created forecast is a straight statistical forecast. Statistical forecasts often deliver better forecasts than a human planner, because they are unbiased.

But sometimes human planners have additional information about events (promotions). These events can lead to significant changes in demand patterns, which might not be considered in standard time series analysis models.
Therefore, it is important to combine the advantages of both statistical and judgmental forecasting.
SAP APO DP offers the possibility to plan promotions separately from the statistical forecasting and combine both results in the end to the total forecast.

To plan promotions, the planner needs additional key figures, such as a key figure for at least one promotion and a key figure for the final forecast, which is the sum of the statistical forecast and the promotion. The advantage is that by planning promotions separately the statistical forecast stays unbiased.
For planning promotions in SAP APO DP some prerequisites have to be met concerning the settings of the planning area, the Planning Book and the Data View.
Additionally, at least the key figure "Promotion" has to be assigned to the Planning Area. If you wish to see the promotion key figure in Interactive Demand Planning, a Data View containing a row for the promotion key figures needs to be created.
Thus the key figures are defined in the planning area you should add the mentioned key figures in the actual Planning Area of the Frutado AG (FRU_AREA_PLAN).

Because this indepth stream should not influence the continuous planning of the Frutado AG, a new Planning Area (FRU_AREA_PLAN_PROMO), with corresponding Planning Book and Data View to show the promotion planning feature has been created. Therefore, the original Planning Area was copied and the two key figures Promotion 1 (9APROM1) and Total Forecast (9ATOTFC) were added. Because these two key figures were also assigned to a new Planning Book and Data View, they are visible in the Interactive Planning.
You can see how to create a Planning Book and all other necessary administrative steps in the Basic-Stream.
In this lesson we use exclusively the new Planning Area.

item.title: Statistical Forecasting
Monitoring the forecast quality with the Alert Monitor
Creating an Alert-Forecast-Profile
item.dc:description:
Creating an Alert-Forecast-Profile 

For using the Alert feature of the SAP APO, an Alert Profile has to be created.
This lesson shows how to create an Alert-Forecast-Profile.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 3 min.

item.title: Creating a Diagnosis Group
item.dc:description:
Creating a Diagnosis Group Forecasts 

In the Diagnosis Group the planner can set the thresholds for the forecast errors.
If these thresholds are exceeded, the system will carry out an Alert.

In this lesson you learn how to create a Diagnosis Group. You create the Diagnosis Group by maintaining the forecast profile.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 min.

item.title: Using the Alert feature
item.dc:description:
Using the Alert feature 

To use the Alert feature, you have to assign the Alert Profile and the Diagnosis Group to the current Planning Book. You can do this in the Interactive Demand Planning.

The system then triggers Alerts, if the thresholds are exceeded.

In this lesson you see how the system carries out an Alert, if you choose a wrong forecasting model, where the forecasting errors are much larger than before.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 3 min.

Monitoring the forecast quality with the Alert Monitor 

After selecting a forecasting model, it is important to observe the quality of the forecasts.
For example, the demand pattern of an Aggregated Group may change from constant to seasonal. The selected forecast model may no longer deliver accurate results anymore.
If the planner uses the Alert feature of the SAP APO, the system will send an alert if a certain threshold of a forecast error is exceeded.

item.title: Analyzing the forecast results
item.dc:description:
Analyzing the forecast results 

After executing a forecast it is useful to analyze the forecasted results and to check if the quality of the forecast is appropriate to the needs of your company.
In SAP APO the "Interactive Demand Planning" desktop is the tool to analyze the forecasts!
The "Interactive Demand Planning Desktop" consists basically of two components.
The selection area, also called "Selector", is the most important tool for searching, sorting and organizing information. You find it on the left side of the "Interactive Demand Planning Desktop".
The second component is the workspace on the right side of the desktop, where you can see the chosen time series.
By clicking the "Univariate Forecast" button, the "Change Mode" is entered. This is the most important desktop to analyze and change the settings and results of the univariate forecast!
In this lesson you learn how you can check the results of the forecasts.
Additionally you have the possibility to learn more about forecasting models and forecasting errors. Just follow the particular links in the lesson.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 10 min.

item.title: Improving the forecast quality
item.dc:description:
Improving the forecast quality 

The SAP APO DP offers a wide range of forecasting models.
As there is no "best" forecasting model, which fits all data patterns, an important task of the demand-planner is to find out which forecasting model is the best fitting one for the time series s/he has to forecast.
In the Frutado AG, the Aggregate Group FRU_SEAS1_DP has a seasonal pattern. There are special models to forecast seasonal patterns, so we can focus on comparing the forecast results of the seasonal models and select the one with the lowest ex-post forecasting error.
We will select the model which generates the lowest MAPE. MAPE has the advantage that it meassures the advantage of the single errors in each period . That means you can see how many percent you forecast deviates from the actuals in average. Therefore MAPE is a robust measure of forecast errors.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 5 min.

Statistical Forecasting 

The statistical forecasting applications in SAP APO DP make it possible to create unbiased forecasts for a lot of products in just a few seconds.

The Demand Planning in APO offers a wide range of statistical forecasting procedures. All of the quantitative methods try to take the historical key figures into account.
Basically, there are two different approaches to statistical forecasting: Time series analysis and causal methods.
Time series analysis(univariate forecasting) assumes that the demand for a product follows a specific pattern. Therefore, the task of a forecasting method is to estimate the pattern from the history of observations. Future forecasts can then be calculated using this estimated pattern. The advantage of this method is that it only requires past observations of demand.
In univariate forecasting, SAP APO DP distinguishes between the following time series patterns:

  • Constant model - The demand is constant with a random noise which cannot be estimated by a forecasting method
  • Trend model - The demand increases or decreases constantly over a longer period with only random noise
  • Seasonal model - The demand has a fixed pattern, which repeats every T periods. The peaks of demand show a large variation from a constant average
  • Trend-seasonal model - A seasonal demand pattern with a constantly increasing or decreasing average
  • Intermitted Model - The demand is sporadic
  • No changes to last year - The demand for next year is expected to be the same as last year.

With these models it is possible to approximate almost all time series.
In the Frutado AG case there are just two of those models represented: The constant (FRU_CONST1_DP to FRU_CONST3_DP) and the seasonal model (FRU_SEAS1_DP and FRU_SEAS2_DP). In indepth stream the example FRU_SEAS1_DP is used to show some interesting features of univariate forecasting of SAP APO DP.
The second approach to statistical forecasting are causal models. These assume that the demand process is determined by some known factors. For the Frutado AG one could assume that the demand for ice tea is larger on warm days. So the temperature would be the independent variable for ice tea sales.
As the Frutado AG does not use causal models, these will not be explained further

In-Depth Stream for Demand Planning

After having calculated the forecasts for all products of the Frutado AG, the In-Depth Stream describes the Demand Planning Module in greater detail. The first section shows how judgemental forecasting can be implemented by creating a promotion. Statistical forecasting is the topic of the second section, where an alert is used to monitor the forecast quality.

Demand Planning 

One of the targets of Supply Chain Management is to fulfill customer demand, which in almost all cases is not known precisely. Many decisions in a supply chain must be taken prior to the point in time when customer demand becomes known. These decisions must be based on forecasted customer demand – also called demand forecast. The process of this action is called demand planning.

Figure 1 illustrates the demand planning process according to the APO. After initial configuration tasks are completed, planning and coordination tasks recur periodically.


For more information concerning the Planning Area Administration please follow this link.

To begin with this modul please open the project "Transferring Data from an InfoCube to a Planning Version".

item.title: Supply Network Planning
SNP Master Data
Location
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Locations for SNP

Locations are required for procurement, production, and storage of products or components. This short lesson shows where you can maintain the locations of the Frutado supply chain. You learn how to choose a location type, the time zone, and the local calendar.

SAP APO allows for more than ten location types. However, in the Frutado case only distribution centers, production plants, and customers locations are needed. But as each Frutado customer is assigned to exactly one distribution center, the customer locations are not relevant for the SNP model.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: 3 min.

item.title: Transportation Lane
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Transportation Lanes for SNP

Transportation lanes represent the connections between the different locations of the Frutado supply chain. Thus, they are crucial for mapping the material flows.

Since we assume that Frutado has its own fleet of trucks only one means of transportation is provided. Furthermore, we assume that trucks never become a bottleneck in the medium term, hence, no capacity constraints are modeled. Besides, the duration and costs for the use of a transportation lane are equal for all products because all products are beverages with no product specific requirements.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 2 min.

item.title: Location Product
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Location Products for SNP

Location products are products, whose parameters are dependent on the location they are related to. For example storage costs of a product do not only depend on the characteristics of the product, but also on the place where it is stored. And this holds for some other attributes of the Frutado products, too.
This lesson displays the relevant parameters and where to edit them.

The Frutado AG holds the complete product range (19 products) in all three distribution centers. Consequently, there are 3 x 19 = 57 location products solely for the possible combinations of distribution centers and products. At an individual production plant, only a part of the entire product portfolio can be produced. Hence, there are just 29 location products related to the production plants. For further information about the production possibilities, please read the general information about the Frutado AG.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 5 min.

item.title: Resource
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Resources for SNP

Various resources are needed to be able to produce and transport the products. Transportation is performed by a third party logistics and, hence, the corresponding resources do not represent a bottleneck. However, scarce production resources have to be modellled explicitly in order to make the best use of it.
The resource consumption and according production costs are maintained in the PPMs that are described in the next lesson. Thus, the focus in this lesson is put on the adjustment of available capacity and the definition of overtime.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 4 min.

item.title: Production Process Model
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Production Process Models
for SNP

Production Process Models are very essential for the SNP. They determine which operations, activities, components, and resources are needed for a specific production process.

In this lesson you get to know the structure of a typical Frutado production process model (PPM) and how to maintain the SNP relevant parameters.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 5 min.

Maintaining the SNP Master Data 

The master data includes basic information about products, locations, and resources. It is used consistently throughout planning and should remain unchanged for a longer period of time.

Some Master data are specific for the use of the SNP optimizer (e.g. the production process model). And although master data is used by all APO modules, it is necessary to maintain specific SNP relevant parameters for the use in the optimizer. For the SNP the following master data is of importance:

  • Locations
  • Transportation Lanes
  • Location Products
  • Resources
  • Production Process Models (PPM).

Hence, this part of the DVD is about maintaining the SNP relevant parameters for the master data types specified above. In the following lessons, you get to know these parameters and learn how to adjust them.

item.title: Model Building
Frutado SNP Model
item.dc:description:
The Frutado SNP Model

Before you start the "Supply Chain Engineer" it is helpful to think about how to describe the planning problem of the Frutado AG in a model. Detailed information about the Frutado planning situation is already given in the general "Frutado AG" part. Hence, this presentation focuses on the SNP relevant objectives and constraints of the basic linear planning model.

Note: Moreover, the management wants to analyze the effect of further restrictions like minimum production lot sizes. These change the model from a linear to mixed-integer one and are investigated in the In-Depth part ot the SNP lesson.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: 5 min.

item.title: Assigning Master Data to the Model
Assigning Master Data to the Model Demo
Assigning Master Data to the Model Practice

item.dc:description:
Assigning Master Data to the Planning Model

After the master data has been set up for the SNP module, the next step is to assign the corresponding objects to the Frutado model. These are the locations, resources, location products, and PPMs. In a further step, transportation relations between the locations are created.

With the help of the Supply Chain Engineer, you can build the network for the Frutado supply chain. This model is the basis for all SNP planning functions, but it is also essential for the other APO modules. Thus, this step is really crucial.

 

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: 5 min.

item.title: Accounting and Steering Costs
item.dc:description:
Accounting and Steering Costs

In this lesson, the cost model for the Frutado AG is presented. By implementing the SNP cost structure you have to distinguish between real and steering costs. Steering costs are used to penalize violation of soft constraints, for example they can be used to influence inventory targets or the customer service level. 

As already known, the majority of costs can be maintained in the master data records. In this lesson, a further option, i. e. "Maintain Cost Directory", is presented. If you want to create a cost function, you also need these transactions.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: 3 min.

Model Building

The next step of the Supply Network Planning is to create the "Supply Chain Model" that builds the basis for planning with SAP APO. It represents the overall supply network and links all relevant master data. Thus, before you can create the "Supply Chain Model" it is fundamental that all relevant master data is already ready for input.

The model is built by the SAP APO tool "Supply Chain Engineer". This is shown for the Frutado model in the "Assigning Master Data to the Model" demo. But first a brief introduction into the objectives and constraints of the Frutado model is given. In the last lesson of this part, you learn how to implement an appropriate cost model.

item.title: SNP Planning Run
SNP Planning Book
item.dc:description:
The SNP Planning Book

Planning books are composed of multiple data views. These data views show the content (e.g. key figures, characteristics, the planning horizon, bucket size) based on a certain layout for interactive planning. The customization of planning books enables the use of just one planning area for different planning tasks. For example the DP and the SNP module both have planning books based on the same planning area.

The SNP as well as the Deployment Optimizer are started in the planning book that additionally provides graphical support to analyze the generated plans. This is shown in a later lesson.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 4 min.

item.title: SNP Optimization
item.dc:description:
The SNP Optimization Process

The Frutado management wants to use the cost-based optimizer to create a minimum cost master plan for the overall Frutado supply chain. The optimizer determines the optimal sources of supply, the inventory at the end of the buckets, and available overtime capacity to fulfill the forecasted weekly demand provided by the demand planning module.

In order to understand how Frutado constraints and requirements are implemented, it is helpful to know the lessons "SNP Master Data" and "Model Building" as well as the lesson "SNP Planning Book". 

To analyze the planning results on your own, an excel file is provided additionally. The export of such a file is a standard fuction of SAP APO.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 6 min.

The SNP Planning Run

Now the weekly SNP planning run is started to create a master plan for the entire Frutado supply chain. Therefore, the Frutado management wants to use the cost based SAP APO optimizer.

In the first lesson of this section, the interactive planning book for SNP is introduced. If you already know the planning book from the demand planning lessons, you can skip and continue with the next lesson "SNP Optimization".

item.title: Transfer of the Planning Results
Integration of SNP and PP/DS
Integration of SNP and PP/DS Demo
Integration of SNP and PP/DS Practice

item.dc:description:
Integration of SNP and PP/DS

In order to transfer the SNP results to the PP/DS module, it is necessary to understand the links between these two modules and how to define them. These links are for example the planning horizon and the master data. Therefore it is helpful if you have finished the lessons "Maintaining Resources for SNP" and "Maintaining PPMs for SNP" before you continue with this lesson.


Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 3 min.

item.title: Conversion SNP2PPDS
item.dc:description:
Conversion of SNP orders to PP/DS

The PP/DS plans based on the SNP decisions about sources of the supply, inventory at the end of the buckets and overtime capacity. Hence, the corresponding data has to be transferred to the PP/DS. The management decides to use the APO tool "Conversion SNP2PPDS" to provide the SNP results for the PP/DS module. In this lesson you learn how use this tool.

Note that you have to consider the details given in lesson "Integration of SNP and PP/DS" if you use the conversion tool.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 4 min.

Transfer of the SNP Planning Results

The SNP optimizer plans bucket oriented, i. e. without defining the sequence of the orders within a bucket. But setup times and costs strongly depend on the sequence of the orders. Thus, the Frutado management wants to refine the SNP plan with the help of the APO PP/DS module for the next 4 weeks. Hence, the SNP planning results have to be transferred.

item.title: In-Depth Stream
Copy the Planning Version for SNP
Copy the Planning Version for SNP Demo
Copy the Planning Version for SNP Practice

item.dc:description:
Copy the Planning Version for Alternative Models

In order not to disturb the operations of the operating system, a seperate planning version should be used for the simulation of alternative models. Therefore, all master and transactional data of the SNP planning area is copied from the current planning version into a new one. This procedure is shown in the subsequent lesson.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 2 min.

item.title: Modeling Discrete Overtime
item.dc:description:
Modeling Discrete Capacity Extensions in SNP

Without using overtime, the Frutado AG produces 24 hours on 5 days a week. In order to increase production capacity up to 24 hours, overtime can be used on Saturdays. However, it seems economically reasonable to the management that if overtime is worked on Saturday, the complete 24 hours have to be scheduled. This is implemented by modeling discrete capacity extensions.

Again, an excel file is provided to analyze the results on your own.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 3 min.

item.title: Anticipating Setup Times and Costs
Result Logs - MIP with Setup Times and Costs
Anticipating Setup Times and Costs Demo
Anticipating Setup Times and Costs Practice

item.dc:description:
Anticipating Setup Times and Costs in the SNP

In the basic linear Frutado model, the time needed for setups is anticipated by reducing the available bucket capacity of each ressource by a global discount. But this reduces available capacity far too much if for example only a single product is produced on the resource. Hence, the capacity is not completely utilized yielding to increased costs.

In this lesson, the effect of modeling setup times and costs in the PPMs is investigated to allow simple lot-sizing on the SNP level. Therefore, the SNP setup times and costs are set equal to the average over the sequence dependent setup times and costs of the PP/DS, respectively.

In this lesson it is shown how to implement this approach. But note that this option changes the linear model into a mixed-integer one. Thus, model complexity and runtime increase.

Duration of this lesson:
Demo Mode: approx. 4 min.

In-Depth Stream for SNP

After having modeled and analyzed the basic elements of the Frutado supply chain, this section presents further extensions that change the linear model into a mixed-integer one. Corresponding to the process depicted in the SNP planning circle, the effect of alternative model formulations is simulated.

Supply Network Planning (SNP)

The Supply Network Planning coordinates the material flows across the supply chain functions procurement, production, and distribution. The task of the SNP is to generate an optimal mid-term production plan and to make sourcing decisions. All decisions are made simultaneously on the basis of a global supply chain model. By balancing the various costs, the SNP optimizer derives the optimal procurement, production, and inventory levels for each product type and period. It is decided whether to build up seasonal stock, to select sources of supply, or to extend capacity by overtime.

Your task is now to generate a supply network plan for the Frutado AG supply chain that covers a planning horizon of 26 weeks with weekly buckets.

In order to build the supply chain model, it is inevitable to understand the SNP relevant master data and the special requirements for the Frutado AG. Hence, this is presented in the first section "SNP Master Data". Based on the master data, you learn how to build the Frutado supply chain model in the second section "Model Building". After that, the planning run can be started. This is performed in the third section "SNP Planning Run". In the fourth section "Transfer of the Planning Results", you learn how to transfer your planning results to the PP/DS. Therefore, you need to understand the integration of SNP and PP/DS. The whole SNP planning process is illustrated by the diagram above.

The "In-Depth Stream" provides further model variants for the SNP.

item.title: Production Planning / Detailed Scheduling
PP/DS Master Data
Setup Activities
item.dc:description:
Create Sequence-Dependent Setup Activities

In the Frutado AG, setup activities are required when changing the bottle type and the flavor of the beverage. These are considered to be sequence dependent. E.g., changing the flavor from a light flavor like Banana to a strong like Cherry takes less time than vice versa.

The sequence-dependent setup activities are represented by setup matrices. A setup matrix has to be created for each production resource. To each setup activity, a setup group or setup key is assigned to determine the required setup time and the associated costs.

The setup matrices indicate the possible setup transitions of the predecessor to the successor activity as well as the setup times and setup costs. While it would be possible to define all setup transitions using a nXn matrix (n being the number of products), this would require a big table which would cause stress to the performance of the system  because the system has to search for the associated setup transition whenever there is an order planned. The fact that usually many products have very similar setup requirements can be exploited to reduce the number of entries in the table, by splitting the definition of setups into setup groups and setup keys.

Setup groups can contain similar products, which have (mostly) the same setup transitions (in regard to time and costs). A so called standard setup transition indicates the setup transition between two setup groups. If exception setup transitions between certain products of the groups are different from the standard setup transition, individual exception setup transitions can be defined. These setup transitions are represented by setup keys which are assigned to the setup groups.

Remark: If setup activites are not sequence dependent, setup groups and matrices are not required. Then, the setup times and costs are maintained directly in the PP/DS-PPMs.

item.title: PP/DS PPM
item.dc:description:
Create a PP/DS-PPM

A PPM describes the production process for producing one or more products on a non-order-specific basis.

Due to the bucket nature of the SNP, in SNP-PPMs no setup activities with sequence-dependent setup times can be maintained, only discrete capacity consumption. In addition, a production activity can only have a firmly assigned mode. To prevent overloading of the SNP model, the detail of these PPMs is usually limited.

In PP/DS the detailed planning of production takes place. Therefore, detailed PPMs, which include all activities, components and accurate capacity consumptions, must be used for planning in continuous time. This means they contain to-the-second information about the duration of the individual process steps.

For sequence dependent setups, a PP/DS-PPM accepts for each operation the assignment of a setup group / key. While planning the operation on a resource, the APO determines the resulting setup requirements from the setup matrix.

Remark: The APO can use the more detailed PP/DS-PPM plan to generate a SNP-PPM automatically.

Create the master data for PP/DS

The master data include basic information which describe the supply chain, e.g. products, locations or resources. These data are usually unchanged over a longer period of time for a consistent planning.

Master data can be created directly in the relevant APO component or they can be transferred from an ERP system to APO. Additionally to the master data of SNP, the following master data are required for the PP/DS:

  • setup groups/keys

  • setup matrices

  • PP/DS PPMs.

In this learning section you will learn how to create these master data in PP/DS.

item.title: Interactive Production Planning Tools
Product View
item.dc:description:
Construction of the Product View

The Product View displays information on requirements, receipts and stocks for a location product. 

In the Product View you can process orders, receipts and requirements for a location product manually.

item.title: Product Panning Table
item.dc:description:
Construction of the Product Planning Table

In the interactive planning of APO, the Product Planning Table is a multifunctional and flexible interactive planning tool, which provides a periodic, aggregated view of the production and external procurement. This tool can be used for planning production quantities and to evaluate the results of the automatic planning runs using heuristics or the Optimizer. So it is possible to examine the planned orders and requirements of a procurement planning and to evaluate the resulting capacity situation and identify problems in form of alert messages.

In the Product Planning Table you can access heuristics and optimization where you can automatically create production orders and a schedule:

  • The heuristics are executed for a selected product in the Production Planning Table. To execute a heuristic you can choose between Product Heuristic and Variable Heuristic. If you choose the Product Heuristic, settings defined in the master data of the product are used. If other settings should be used, this can be done using the Variable Heuristic.
  • Unlike the heuristics, the Optimizer is executed for selected production resources.

Additionally, of course manual changes can be performed to alter the result of the heuristics or of the optimizer.

Remark: The functions of the Heurisitcs and the Optimizer are explained in the PP/DS Production Planning learning sections.

item.title: Detailed Scheduling Planning Board
item.dc:description:
Construction of the Detailed Scheduling Planning Board

The Detailed Scheduling Planning Board is used for the graphical representation of the planning situation with a focus on the different aspects of scheduling. For example, it is possible to show the resource loading situation or pegging relationships between orders and receipts over time.

Various scheduling functions and heuristics are available. Furthermore, the Detailed Scheduling Planning Board is used for the interactive solution of planning problems. The interactive scheduling in the Detailed Scheduling Planning Board can be used to treat planning problems not solved by the heuristics or the optimizer manually and to use expert knowledge about details not maintained in the system .

> 

Interactive Production Planning Tools

Interactive planning is used to solve planning problems such as shortages, order delays and resource overloads, and to process typical interactive planning tasks, such as:

  • Creating procurement proposals for manually planned products

  • Sequencing on resources

  • Campaign definition.

In this learning section the structure and functions of the most important Interactive Production Planning Tools will be explained to demonstrate the possibilities of interactive planning. Thereby various views and charts will be shown.

Remark: All changes are simulative until you have saved.

item.title: Integration of the DP Data in PP/DS
Copy Planning Version
item.dc:description:
Copy the planning version

For the PP/DS we need to load daily demands into the liveCache. To prevent demands from occuring double, beforehand the liveCache needs to be purged from the aggregated demands that were used in the SNP. However, for SNP we still want to keep the data, so in a first step a new planning version FRU_PV_PP is created as a copy of planning version FRU_PV_SNP.

item.title: Integration DP Forecast Data
item.dc:description:
Integrate the Detailed DP Forecast Datas in the PP/DS Planning

The system does not distinguish in the liveCacheliveCache

The liveCache is a database engine for managing complex objects in SAP solutions such as mySAP Supply Chain Management (Advance Planner and Optimizer). In solutions of this type, large volumes of data must be permanently available and modifiable. For this reason, an enhancement was made to the relational database system to enable the actual data structures and data flows (such as networks and relationships) to be mapped more easily and effectively. - SAP Help

 between aggregated mid term and detailed short term demand data. So the aggregated forecast data of the SNP are also visible for the PP/DS and production orders would be created to fulfill them. However, since these are the aggregated detailed demands and those shall be also in the liveCache for daily planning, those demands would be conisdered two times. So we replace these aggregated forecasts by detailed forecast requirements for the PP/DS Horizon. For that, we first have to delete the aggregated forecasts for the SNP planning within the PP/DS horizon of the liveCache. Secondly, the detailed forecasts will be loaded from the DP module into the liveCache.

Having the detailed daily demands, the PP/DS can then create and schedule production orders to satisfy them on time.

Integration of the detailed DP Data in the PP/DS planning

In this section the weekly aggregated forecast data that was used for the SNP will be removed from the liveCache and daily forecast data is loaded to the liveCache from the DP module.

item.title: PP/DS Production Planning
Heuristic Run
Execute HEU_PLAN_STANDARDLOTS
item.dc:description:
Execute HEU_PLAN_STANDARDLOTS

You can use this heuristic, which is based on the algorithm HEU_PLAN_STANDARDLOTS, to execute procurement planning to cover product requirements. During procurement planning, the heuristic is able to create new receipts. To determine the procurement quantities, the heuristic uses the standard lot-sizing procedure and the lot size settings from the location product master or from the heuristic settings.

Procedure

1.  The heuristic updates the pegging relationships and executes a net requirements calculation.

The heuristic does not consider not transfered SNP receipts* in the PP/DS horizon during the net requirements calculation; instead it deletes them. Transfered SNP receipts, on the other hand, are retained and are taken into consideration during the net requirements calculation.

2.  The heuristic executes a procurement quantity calculation to create receipts for the uncovered requirements identified by the net requirements calculation.

3.  If the receipt quantities that the heuristic calculates for an uncovered requirement exceed this requirement (e.g. because of fixed lot sizes), the heuristic pegs this surplus to the following requirement.

4.  The heuristic executes a source determination (selecting a PPM and the mode) based on the procurement quantities and the desired availability dates.

5.  The heuristic plans each newly created order on the resources and pegs it to receipts.

*: compare the SNP-lesson "Conversion of SNP2PPDS"

Heuristic Run

In the interactive planning and in the production planning run, heuristics are used to automatically execute planning tasks. In PP/DS, a heuristic is a planning function that executes one or more planning steps for selected objects (products, resources, operations, or line networks, depending on the planning focus).

SAP delivers standard algorithms which can be used to define various heuristics. In general, heuristics can be classified into the following categories:

  • Procurement planning heuristics are used to create procurement proposals for uncovered product requirements by external procurement and/or in-house production. The heuristic uses a heuristic-specific MRP procedure and lot-sizing procedure.

  • Service heuristics to process specific aspects of existing planning. Service heuristics include, for example, heuristics that can adjust order dates on a multilevel basis, or that can change order priorities.

  • Heuristics for process control can be used to control the planning process in single- or multilevel procurement planning for several products, like for example for an end product and its components.

item.title: Optimization Run
item.dc:description:
Execute the PP/DS Optimization

Optimization is used in PP/DS after a heuristic run to create the production orders has been executed to improve the solution. It cannot create new production orders or delete those already planned.

With optimization production dates and the resource allocation for operations are improved in regard to one ore more of the following criterias. The criterias taken into account and their weights are defined in the optimization profile:

  • Makespan
    • In SAP APO this is defined as the time span between the earliest possible start time of a production plan specified by the user and the end of the last operation in the optimized plan.

  • Total Setup Times and Total Setup costs
    • This criteria is used to take setup times and costs into account. The system determines setup times and setup costs that are dependent on sequence from the setup matrix.

  • Delay Costs
    • With these criteria the improvement of the schedule takes costs that are associated with the delayed completion of orders or activities into account. The following optimization criteria are available:

    • The sum of the delay costs
    • The maximum delay costs.
    There is a delay when:

    • A receipt date is later than a requirement date
    • The latest feasible start or finish date for an activity is before the actual start or finish date.

  • Mode costs
    • The mode costs for an activity are the costs that are incurred when executing an activity in a particular mode. It is possible to maintain the fixed and variable costs in the optimization profile depending on the mode priority.

The weights that you apply to the various times or costs in the optimization profile when defining the objective function reflect the importance of each problem for your schedule.

For the optimization a Genetic Algorithm, which is a stochastic meta-heuristic, is employed. It works by modifying the existing schedule of the orders to find a better result according to the objective function. It may be set to end after a certain time or if no more improvements can be found. Note that in both cases the final result is not necessarily the true optimum. The sequence with the best objective value can then be saved or serve as a starting point for further interactive planning.

item.title: Result of the automatic Planning
item.dc:description:
Result of the automatic Planning

To see the result of the automatic planning run, the Product Planning Table can be used with its different views of the planning situation. These views are used to evaluate the requirement and procurement situation of  products as well as the resource utilization and allocation. In case of an overloaded resource you can determine the causing requirements and reschedule those orders.

In this lesson, we will check the requirements and the resource allocation. Furthermore we will check if the resources are overloaded and how many requirements are covered by a single order due to the lot size of maximum 4 hl which affects the pegging structure.

item.title: Interactive Planning and Evaluation
item.dc:description:
Interactive planning and evaluation

With the Interactive Planning, especially the DS planning board, exists a tool to solve planning problems manually. Therfore the following options are available:

  • If there is a product shortage, it is possible to create a corresponding receipt.

  • If a requirement is not covered, because the availability date of an existing receipt is after the requirements date, it is possible to change the date of the receipt .

  • If certain orders should not be changed by automatic planning, it is possible to fix those orders.

  • If the system should not change the assignment of a receipt element to a requirements element, you can fix the pegging relationship.

  • If sequence or the resource allocation of orders should be changed, it is possible to call up the detailed scheduling planning board. In the detailed scheduling planning board, the rescheduling of orders and operations to different dates or resources can be done.

For analyzing scheduling and scheduling problems various tools are available in Production Planning:

  • Logs
    The system automatically generates a planning or scheduling log for a planning run. These logs contain messages that the system issues during the planning. These logs can be used to analyze planning problems and identify the causes of the problems.

  • Order and Resource Evaluations
    With the Order and Resource Evaluations it is possible to get performance figures about the Resource load, the Work-in-Process stocks, the Capacity utilisation, the Operations, the Orders and the Production.

PP/DS Production Planning

In this learning section a production planning run will be executed. In the first lesson a procurement planning will be executed by using a PP/DS heuristic. Thereby orders will be created to cover the stock transfers, which were transfered from the SNP module. In the second lesson the production schedule will be improved by use of the PP/DS Optimizer to cover the daily demands under consideration of costs and capacities. The result of the automatic planning are checked in lesson after the optimization. In the last lesson we will change the planning interactively and afterwards evaluate the resource load.

item.title: In-Depth-Stream
Machine breakdown
item.dc:description:
Machine breakdown

In this lesson the handling of a short-term machine breakdown will be demonstrated. The PP/DS Optimizer can reschedule product orders to different time windows and additionally to different production resources at the same location, if several modes are entered in their PPMs.

Note that for long-term machine breakdowns, it is useful to adjust the planning of the SNP module as well, to consider the changed capacities and explore the possibility to employ other production locations.

item.title: Short term Requirement
item.dc:description:
Short term Requirement

In this scenario we want to aquire a new customer who has an urgent demand for a fresh supply of beverages. Because no receipts are available and the safety stock is not large enough, new short term orders have to be planned.

As the production line can be overloaded by the additional requirements, we need to prioritize the production orders which are linked with the short term requirements over production orders that are based only on forecasts. This way we can make sure that the customer demand will be covered in time.

In-Depth-Stream

The handling of two business occurrences is demonstrated in the respective lesson with the PP/DS Modul.These incidences occur unexpected and on short notice and so have not been taken into account in the midterm planning.

Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling

The module Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS) can be used to plan orders detailed and in sequence for a short horizon. In the Frutado Case the horizon is set to 28 days. Functions and objectives of PP/DS are:

  • Planning of the material provision

  • Optimal utilization of resources

  • Identification of a cost and resource utilization optimal sequence

  • Consideration of unexpected occurrences on the companies planning as well as on those of the whole Supply Chain.

The following figure shows the planning procedure of the PP/DS modul:

The objective of the PP/DS in the Frutado Case is to plan the procurement and to generate an optimal production plan. This is explained in the five PP/DS learning sections. To execute PP/DS planning, new master data have to be defined, which will be presented in the first learning section. Then, the weekly aggregated forecast data used in the SNP have to be removed from the liveCache and be replaced with daily forecast data, which will be shown in the second learning section. In the third learning section, the structure and the functions of the most important Interactive Production Planning Tools will be shown to demonstrate the possibilities of interactive planning. In the fourth learning section, a production planning run will be carried out and the results will be analyzed. In the final learning section, the In-Depth Stream, the handling of two common business occurrences, a machine breakdown and a short-term change in material requirement, will be demonstrated.

item.title: Global Available-to-Promise
General Settings for Global ATP
Maintain Global Settings for Availability Check
Maintain Global Settings for Availability Check Demo
Maintain Global Settings for Availability Check Practice

item.dc:description:
Maintain Global Settings for Availability Check

In this step you determine the global settings for availability checks. You are able to:  

  • allow/disallow the Import of Customizing data from the connected ERP-system using the Core Interface (CIF) integration model
  • define bucket parameters
  • make sure that the updating of ATP time series is activated in Model and Version Management of APO



 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Maintain Category
item.dc:description:
Maintain Category

In this section you can look at the pre-defined categories of SAP APO. The categories are part of the settings for the scope of check that is used for the product availability check. They are also important for rules-based availability checks and product allocations.

Note: In this step you should also check the Product View of PP/DS in order to see the category types of the elements that are listed there.


 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Maintain Business Event
item.dc:description:
Maintain Business Event

The business event describes an action within a business and its environment. It initiates the product availability check.

Usually the business event is transferred from a connected Online-Transaction-Processing-System (OLTP-system) via CIF integration model. Together with the check mode the business event determines the check instructions.

In this activity you check whether all relevant business events are created. 

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

item.title: Maintain Check Mode
item.dc:description:
Maintain Check Mode

The check mode is a grouping indicator for products. Togehter with the business event the check mode determines the type and scope of availability checks.

Note: You should also enter the check mode in the location-specific product master data (see in section "Maintain ATP Groups").

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

item.title: Maintain Check Instructions
item.dc:description:
Maintain Check Instructions

In this section you check whether the necessary check instructions are defined. The check instructions determine type and scope of availability checks.

As precondition you already maintained a business event and a check mode. In fact the check instructions are determined from the combination of check mode and business event. You can have a look at the valid combinations of check modes and business events in the check instructions.

The following settings that you determine in the check instructions are relevant for the Frutado case:

  • basic methods to be executed
  • the sequence of the executed basic methods
  • use of rules-based availability check
  • immediate start of rules-based ATP
  • calling production

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

General Settings for Global ATP

In order to use the functions of Global ATP you must make the general settings relevant for Global ATP. You maintain the settings for Global ATP in Customizing of SAP APO. The relevant settings include the following:

  • Maintain Global Settings for Availability Check
  • Maintain Category
  • Maintain Business Event 
  • Maintain Check Mode
  • Maintain Check Instructions

item.title: Settings for the Product Availability Check
Maintain ATP Groups
item.dc:description:
Maintain ATP Groups

An ATP Group is a combination of settings created for the product availability check.

The ATP Group has to be maintained in Customizing of SAP APO and entered in the location-specific product master data.

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Maintain Check Control and Scope of Check
Maintain Check Control and Scope of Check Demo
Maintain Check Control and Scope of Check Practice

item.dc:description:
Maintain Check Control and Scope of Check

In this section you define check control and scope of check. To maintain check control and scope of check an ATP group and a business event already need to be defined.

In fact the check control is determined from the combination of ATP group and business event. You can have a look at the valid combinations of ATP groups and business events in the check control.

The scope of check is part of the check control and contains the selected ATP categories.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

Settings for the Product Availability Check

To execute the product availability check in SAP APO you have to define the relevant settings for the product availability check.

These include the following:  

  • Maintain ATP Groups
  • Maintain Check Control and Scope of Check

item.title: Simulation of the Product Availability Check
Scenario I
item.dc:description:
Scenario I

In the first scenario the following situation is illustrated:

  • customer order arrives at the system
  • customer: FRU_KUNDE_01 (appropriate distribution center is: FRU_DC_01)
  • requested product: FRU_SAFT_01
  • check mode: 030
  • business event: A
  • desired quantity: 2 HL
  • requested date: 20.04.2009

The data of this customer request are chosen arbitrarily for this example.

In this lession you will learn how to simulate a product availbility check. Moreover you learn how to interpret the result screen of the product availability check.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Scenario II
item.dc:description:
Scenario II

In the second scenario the following situation is designed:

  • customer order arrives at the system
  • customer: FRU_KUNDE_01 (appropriate distribution center is: FRU_DC_01)
  • requested product: FRU_SAFT_01
  • check mode: 030
  • business event: A
  • desired quantity: 5 HL
  • requested date: 20.04.2009

In this lession you will learn how to simulate a product availbility check. Moreover you learn how to interpret the result screen of the product availability check.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

Simulation of the Product Availability Check

In order to simulate a product availability check you must have maintained the following settings:

  • General settings for Global ATP
  • Settings for the product availability check

Furthermore you must enter the following check data:

  • Product
  • Location
  • Check mode
  • Business Event
  • Date
  • Quantity

By means of two different scenarios you will learn how to simulate a product availability check and to interpret the results of the checks.

Note: SAP APO is not characterized by this functionality. Most ERP-systems possess such a checking method.

However, with the Global ATP module of SAP APO you apply an alternative to the ATP checks in ERP-systems with enhanced functionality.

Some important advantages are:

  • global rules-based ATP check with substitution of products and locations
  • global product allocation through integrated functionality with the demand planning
  • check against the actual planning results of the other modules, if planning is executed in SAP APO
  • calling production with the CTP functionality
  • check of component availability using the multi-level ATP
  • enlarged functionality of backorder processing
  • high performance using the time series live cache

item.title: Settings for the Rules-Based Availability Check
Integrated Rule Maintenance
Create a Location Determination Procedure
Create a Location Determination Procedure Demo
Create a Location Determination Procedure Practice

item.dc:description:
Create a Location Determination Procedure

In this step you create a new location determination procedure. The location determination procedure is one of the checking steps of rules-based availability check. Informations about location substitutions are saved here.

You are able to make the following settings:

  • determination type 
  • penalty costs to prioritize certain locations (not relevant for the Frutado case)
  • restrict location determination by defining a specific validity period (not relevant for the Frutado case)
  • select activity

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Create a Rule Control
item.dc:description:
Create a Rule Control

In this step you create a new rule control. In the rule control you save informations about how to deal with the procedures that are connected to a rule.

The rule control contains the following elements:

  • access strategy
  • all activities in conjunction with the combination of substitution lists

All activities in conjunction with the combination of substitution lists within the rule control are not considered in the Frutado case. These are the following:

  • defining qualified product/location (used to restrict the substitution list)
  • defining the combination sequence of products and locations (two possible combinations)
  • defining the combination of the product and location lists (union, intersection)
  • using the complement of the combination of product and location lists (yes/no)

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

item.title: Setup a Calculation Profile
item.dc:description:
Setup a Calculation Profile

You create a calculation profile to define the parameters that decide if a rules-based availability check has been performed successfully.

You are able to enter the following informations in the calculation profile:

  • allowed delay (accepted delay of a delivery)
  • allowed early confirmation (accepted number of days for early delivery)
  • consumption limit (specifies a time horizon that prevents stock or early receipts from being consumed by orders that lie too far in the future) 
  • maximum number of partial deliveries (limits the delivery proposals)
  • overdeliveries
  • package size of a partial delivery
  • validity indicator (displays that the value has been maintained)

For the Frutado case you only have to enter values for allowed delay and consumption limit.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Create a Rule
item.dc:description:
Create a Rule

In this step you will learn how to create a rule.

The rules determine how a rules-based availability check is performed.

You have to make the following general settings:

  • rule type: inclusive or exclusive
  • maximum number of substitutions
  • assign a location determination procedure to the rule
  • assign a rule control to the rule
  • assign a calculation profile to the rule

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

Integrated Rule Maintenance

The rules-based availability checks are based on multiple rules that are executed sequentially. 

The rules are defined in the Integrated Rule Maintenance. They decide how the rules-based availability check is performed.

Each rule contains at least one of the following elements:  

  • product substitution procedure
  • location determination procedure
  • location product substitution procedure
  • PPM substitution procedure
  • rule control
  • calculation profile
  • create a rule

In the Frutado case only location substitutions are allowed. Therefore the focus of this lession lies only on the settings for the location determination procedure, rule control, calculation profile and the definition of a rule for the Frutado AG.

item.title: Rule Determination using the Condition Technique
Create Condition Table
item.dc:description:
Create Condition Table

A condition table is a definition of characteristics or criteria that determine the rule usage.

In the rules-based availability check the condition tables hold condition records that define the specific access to a certain rule. During rules-based ATP check the condition records are read from the condition tables. The result depends on the fields in the field catalog that you choose when you create a new condition table. You determine the sequence of the key fields according to when you copied them from the field catalog. The selected fields determine the key for the condition records.

When the systems searches a condition table, the system finds a condition record that is consistent with the specific field values from the sales order that activates the ATP check.

Each successful access to a condition record returns a rule at runtime of the system.

You can define several condition tables in the system. Only specific ones are searched during the rules-based availability check. The access sequences are used to check this.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

item.title: Maintain Rule Strategy
item.dc:description:
Maintain Rule Strategy

In this step you create a rule strategy and assign the condition type of the previous step to it.

The rule strategy defines the individual steps and their evaluation sequence to be followed during the rule determinaton process. Each step is a condition type.

Usually you need only one condition type for each rule strategy.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 2 Min.

item.title: Assign a Rule Strategy
item.dc:description:
Assign a Rule Strategy

In this step you define the activation parameters used to determine a rule strategy and assign them to the previously defined rule strategy. Usually the values for the activation parameters come from a customer order that entered the OLTP-system. When you carry out the rules-based availability check the parameters are transferred to SAP APO. 

You have to define the following activation parameters:

  • Technical scenario: is consistent with the communication technology that activated rules-based availability check. The values are hard-coded in the ERP-system and are transferred to SAP APO from the calling application.
  • Business transaction: corresponds to the business context in which a rules-based availability check should take place. Usually the value is transferred to SAP APO from the calling OLTP-system at runtime and assigned to an order type.
  • Action type: corresponds to the manipulation technique of the calling transaction. These values are hard-coded in the ERP-system and are transferred to SAP APO from the calling application.

Note: Normally the values of the activation parameters have to comply with the values that are transferred from the connected OLTP-system. If this is not guaranteed, the system does not find any rule strategies or rules.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

item.title: Create Access Sequence
item.dc:description:
Maintain Access Sequence

The access sequence is an ordered list of condition tables used to search for condition records that correspond with the values of a sales order. It is essential to find a matching condition record in order to identify the right rule that has to be used in a certain ATP check.

By means of using the access sequence you define:

  • which condition tables are used to access the condition records
  • the sequence in which the allocated condition tables are used

It is possible to link several condition tables to an access sequence.  

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

item.title: Create Condition Type
item.dc:description:
Maintain Condition Type

In this step you determine a condition type and link it to the access sequence you defined in the previous step.

The condition types are used to determine the rules in the rules-based availability check.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 1 Min.

Rule Determination using the Condition Technique

A precondition for this procedure is that you have already defined at least one rule in Integrated Rule Maintenance.

The settings for rule determination and the mechanism for determining the rules are demonstrated using the condition technique.

In order to configure the condition technique you have to execute the following steps:

  • Maintain Field Catalog (already created)
  • Create Condition Table
  • Create Access Sequence
  • Create Condition Type
  • Maintain Rule Strategy
  • Define Rule Strategy Sequence (in case of combining several rule strategies - not relevant for the Frutado case)
  • Assign a Rule Strategy

In the following figure you see the interaction of condition technique and rules for the Frutado case:

A sales order enters the connected OLTP-system (not in the Frutado case). Then the rules-based availability check is executed provided that it is activated.The incomming sales order contains the values of the three activation parameters and tranfers them to SAP APO (not in the Frutado case). When transferring the parameters a rule strategy or rule strategy sequence is found directly. The rule strategy refers to one or more condition types. Each condition type is assigned to an access sequence. A list of accesses to condition tables belongs to this access sequence. Now the matching key combination is searched within these condition tables. In the end a rule is found by comparing the values of the sales order with the values of the condition tables.

Settings for the Rules-Based Availability Check

By means of the rules-based availability check the companies are able to react automatically to incomplete availability of a product.

The rules-based availability check is an iterative process. The defined rules and the according checking results cause the particular subsequent checking steps. The system stops searching for available quantity when a feasible result is achieved. The results of each step are summarized until the requested quantity is found.

The settings you have to make to simulate a rules-based availability check are divided into two areas:

  • Integrated Rule Maintenance
  • Rule Determination using the Condition Technique

The following sections explain the appropriate  settings in detail.

item.title: Simulation of Rules-Based Availability Check
Scenario III
item.dc:description:
Scenario III

In the third scenario the following situation is built:

  • customer order arrives at the system
  • customer: FRU_KUNDE_01 (appropriate distribution center is: FRU_DC_01)
  • requested product: FRU_SAFT_01
  • check mode: 050
  • business event: A
  • desired quantity: 10 HL
  • requested date: 20.04.2009

In scenario II you already carried out a simulative product availability check where the confirmed quantity of the customer`s requested product in the requested location was not large enough. In a further step you also have the possibility to use substitution options, for example check alternative locations for available products, in order to find the remaining open quantity.

In this lession you will learn how to simulate a rules-based availability check. Moreover you learn how to interpret the result screen of the rules-based  availability check.

 

Duration of this Lesson:
Demo Mode: 4 Min.

Simulation of Rules-Based Availability Check

In order to simulate a rules-based availability check you must have maintained the following settings:

  • General settings for Global ATP
  • Settings for the rules-based availability check
  • valid check mode for all substitution products in the location-specific product master data (not for the Frutado case since product substitutions are not possible)
  • activation of rules-based availability check in the check instructions

Furthermore you must enter the following check data:

  • Product
  • Location
  • Check mode
  • Business Event
  • Date
  • Quantity
  • Activation parameters

item.title: Further Functions
Capable-to-Promise (CTP)
item.dc:description:
Capable-to-Promise (CTP)

CTP describes the possibility to call PP/DS during an ATP check, if the required quantity of a product is not completely available. The basic idea of CTP is to create planned orders in PP/DS and check for component availability.

The CTP functionality is usually applied either in a typical make-to-order environment or in cases where planning according to forecasts is not sufficient.

An important advantage of CTP is that both capacities and components availability are checked before a sales order is confirmed.

Steps during the CTP check:

In the following figure you can see the steps that  have to be passed during a CTP check. These steps include both ATP ad PP/DS functionalities:

First of all a sales order enters the connected OLTP-system, for example an ERP-system like SAP ERP. Date and quantity of the sales order are transferred to the ATP module of SAP APO. After the ATP check the requested date and quantity for CTP is calculated in the ATP module. The requested date for CTP is always identical to the requested date of the sales order, wheras the requested CTP quantity might differ from the requested quantity of the sales order depending on the result of a product check that is possibly performed first. In a further step PP/DS is called with these informations. The PP/DS module creates a simulative planned order according to the production restrictions and a simulative demand for the same quantity in order to keep any demand from using this planned order. In a next step PP/DS transfers the availability date for the CTP quantity. Then ATP combines the confirmations of the ATP check with the PP/DS result. Finally the sales order is saved in SAP ERP and transferred to SAP APO. The "simulative" status of the planned order in PP/DS is changed to "normal" and the simulative demand is deleted.

Start of production:

There are different variants to start CTP within the advanced check methods:

  • start production immediately
  • start production after product availability check (receipts are only created for the open quantity)
  • start production after all basic methods

Another possibility to start CTP is to call PP/DS by the location determination procedure of integrated rule maintenance.

The following simplified example helps to understand this procedure. You can see different planned orders of a certain production line. On this production line in a certain plant a specific product of the Frutado AG is produced. The production process only consists of the filling process of the beverages. We assume that the filling time for one production order is one hour. The figure displays all the planned production orders on 17 April 2009 from 08:00 till 12:00 o´clock.
