As you can see already four prodction orders are dispatched. However, in the time period from 09:00 till 10:00 o´clock there is a production capacity of one our available. In this time period you can dispatch the CTP order assumed that enough material is available to produce the required product.

 

 

Nevertheless you should always regard alternative modelling approaches first before you decide to use CTP. If the bottleneck is for example more on the production capacity side, then allocations are considered as a possible alternative to CTP. When the bottleneck is rather the component availability, then multilevel ATP should be prefered.

item.title: Multilevel ATP Check
item.dc:description:
Multilevel ATP Check

The multilevel ATP check is usually used in industry areas where a large part of the value-added activites occur at final assembly.The assemblies on the lower production levels have already been produced before the sales oder enters the system.

The sales order (mainly for configured products) can only be accepted when all components needed to produce the requested endproduct are available in time. However, the product configuration determined by the customer decides which components are needed specifically. This can only be checked at the time of sales oder entry.

In contrast to the CTP check initially no receipt elements are created during the multilevel ATP check. Instead, the checking results are stored in the so-called ATP tree structure. Receipts elements are generated later when the ATP tree structure  is transferred in the PP/DS module. This permits the system improved performance during the check. However, the conclusions on capacity availability and component availability can not be as detailed as in the CTP module.

item.title: Product Allocation
item.dc:description:
Product Allocation

In reality unfortunately unpredictable problems can lead to critical situations in order processing. 

Problems such as breakdowns in production, increased demand as well as shifted or reduced supply must be brought under control before they arise. 

Product allocations provide companies an opportunity to avoid these critical situations in order processing. 

In cases where demand or expected demand exceeds the supply an equal allocation of products and quick reactions to bottlenecks and changing market situations must be ensured.

By means of product allocations you can allocate products for specific customers or regions depending on the period. It is very important to know that allocations are not reservations for actual receipts, but limitations for the sales order confirmation.

Allocations help to avoid that the entire available quantity gets to the first customer and ensure that customers or customer groups are provided with their adequate contingent according to the sales and marketing policies. Generally allocations try to avoid "first come first serve" as this leads to delays of subsequent sales order confirmations or makes confirmation impossible.

Basically you can allocate material according to any criteria. The availability check is successful if there is a product allocation for a specific transaction in the relevant period and this product allocation has not yet been consumed by other requirements.

Further Functions

In this lession you will receive some informations about the fundamental functions Capable-to-Promise (CTP), multi-level ATP and Product Allocation.

These functions are only considered in a theoretical approach.

Global Available-to-Promise (globalATP)

The module globalATP coordinates the short term planning of demand and supply. It helps to fulfill incoming customer orders for the purpose of customer satisfaction.

The first task of this module is the so-called availability check. It decides whether the order should be accepted or not and determines a first, hopefully reliable, delivery date. The module matches the available-to-promise (ATP) quantities of products, i.e. the available inventory and the projected supply, which has been triggered by forecasts (Demand Planning) or already known future sales, with the arriving customer orders.

If a DC is short of the ATP-quantities required desired by an order, some alternatives need to be thought of to find enough available supplies. This procedure is called Shortage Planning, see the following figure.

Certain circumstances may occur between the order promise and the actual delivery, which require a replanning of delivery plans. This surveillance in SAP APO is called Event Driven Quantity Assignment. If a shortage situation occurs, replanning is executed, which may result in repromising modified order quantities or due dates.

As the module globalATP works in a very short-term horizon there are many transactions between the planning system SAP APO and the underlying ERP system SAP R/3. The following figure shows transactions regarding the ATP Check between SAP APO and the ERP, see figure. In the Frutado case, however, the ERP system is not included. Therefore, the entry of orders must be simulated here by defining fictitious orders.

The following sections explain first the necessary settings for the globalATP and the simulation of an ATP availability check. Then one can perform simulations and see the decisions of the ATP module and the resulting order fulfillment.

item.title: Deployment
Master Data Settings
Locations
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Locations for Deployment

Locations are required for procurement, production, and storage of products or components. This short lesson shows where you can maintain the deployment related settings of locations for the Frutado supply chain. You learn how to create category groups to represent the demand and supply figures that should be used for deplyoment planning, and how to assign them to the locations.

In the Frutado project, two classes of demand, customers sales orders/forecasts and DCs forecasts, are considered. The supply figure stems from production quantities produced in plants.

item.title: Products
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Products for Deployment

To run the deployment planning modules the product related penalties should be maintained in master data. These penalties include the no-delivery and late delivery costs at DC and customer locations. Further, the maximum acceptable delay, for late delivered products are maintained here.

This lesson also displays how to set the deployment planning horizons for individual products, how to use the available demand or supply patterns for deployment planning, and how to define priorities for certain products. As customers planning was not considered before this stage, we also define storage costs at customer locations.

item.title: Transportation Lanes
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Transportation Lanes for Deployment

Transportation lanes serve as the connections between different locations of the Frutado supply chain. Thus, they are crucial for mapping the material flows.

Although transportation lanes are defined in the master data section of SNP, this lesson briefly look at some of the deployment related features of transportation lanes.

Master Data Settings

Two data types may be employed in planning a supply chain with SAP APO. These two data types, master data and transaction data, can be differentiated according to their application.

Unlike transaction data that vary as a result of running different planning transactions, master data are fixed in the entire planning period, or are decided on strategic levels and usually remain unchangeable during a sufficiently long horizon.

For instance, introduction of a new production site in the supply chain, or introduction of a new product are belong to master data type. On the other hand, forecast data, and data regarding production and distribution plans, which are subject to change at different planning runs, represent some examples of transaction data. 

In order to run the deployment planning module for the Frutado AG, three categories of master data have to be maintained as:

  • Locations
  • Products
  • Transport connections

This session includes three lessons on how to maintain the above three master data sets.

item.title: Rolling Horizon Based Deployment Planning
Data-View Setting
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Data-Views for Deployment

The deployment data-view, as explained in the SNP module, is almost the same as SNP data-view and is created in the same planning book. However, deployment planning is most often performed in a more detailed time granularity than SNP.

In the Frutaod project, deployment is run for a period of two weeks and on a daily basis. In this lesson, we maintain a data-view with the correct length and granularity to be used for deployment planning.

item.title: Excluding DCs Forecasts and Transport Orders
Excluding DCs Forecasts and Transport Orders Demo
Excluding DCs Forecasts and Transport Orders Practice

item.dc:description:
Excluding Demand Forecasts at DCs and Transport Orders 

In the Frutado project, at the beginning of each week, customer orders are known to the system for the length of one week, and after that we have demand forecasts at DC level.

Therefore, instead of running deployment only on the basis of DC's forecasts, we consider the actual customer orders for the first week to generate a more appropriate deployment plan. Moreover, to generate a more flexible space for deployment planning, we delete the planned stock transports that are generated by the previous planning modules.

In this lesson, we show how to delete these figures.

item.title: Releasing Customer Demands
item.dc:description:
Releasing Customer Demands

In the Frutado project, at the beginning of each week, customer orders are known to the system for the length of one week, and after that we have demand forecasts at DC level. Since, there is no ERP to release feed our system with customer orders, we uploaded customer orders in the system livecatche in the demand planning (DP) module. In this lesson, we show how to consider the uploaded customer orders as customer demand forecasts and release them into our deployment planning version.

Rolling Horizon Based Deployment Planning 

In the Frutado AG, we run the deployment optimization function for a period of two weeks and on a rolling horizon basis.

  • We assume that the system  has been in use for some weeks thereby stocks are available at DCs to fully or partially cover customer demands of the first week.
  • In the second week, confirmed production quantities are deployed between plants and DCs to cover forecasted demands at DCs.

In this learning section the final initialization of the system for running the deployment planning feature based on the rolling horizon concept is carried out. In the first lesson, we show how to maintain an appopriate dataview for deployment planning. Since the Frutado project is not supported through an ERP system, in the second lesson we explain how to release customers demand data, previously uploaded in the livecatche, into our planning version. After uploading customer orders, the DCs demand forecasts of the first week is not required any more. Therefore, we delete them in the last lesson.

item.title: Deployment Optimization
Cost Profile
item.dc:description:
Deployment Cost Profile 

Different cost or revenue-related objectives are considered for modeling the deployment problem.

The solution of the deployment probelm changes on the basis of the weights of each of these objectives.

The deployment cost profile provides planners with a table to assign a weight to each of the objective terms based on the problem instance and the managerial considerations.

In this short lesson we show how to create/maintain a deployment cost profile.

item.title: Optimization Profile
item.dc:description:
Deployment Optimization Profile 

Deployment optimization profile is used to make deployment optimization settings. Many of the settings can be replaced by the respective products master data, explained in the Master data settings section. While defining deployment related settings in product master data provides more flexibility in treating products and locations in different ways, the defined settings in deployment optimization profile are equally appllied to all locations and products. 

Besides SNP optimization and cost profiles, the following profiles might also be employed for deployment optimization which are out of the scope of the Frutado AG:

  • SNP lot size profile
  • SNP optimization bound profile
  • SNP planning profile
  • Parallel processing profile

In this lesson we show how to create/maintain a deployment optimization profile and explain its different settings. More specifically, we discuss the following topics:

  • Deployment solution methods
  • Deployment strategies
  • Priority vs. cost-based deployment
  • Constraints consideration
  • Demand priority settings

At the end the influence of setting different deployment strategies under inventory shortage situation is illustrated.

item.title: Optimization Run
item.dc:description:
Deployment Optimization Run

Running the deployment optimization generates confirmed transport orders based on the defined optimzation and cost profiles. Deployment optimization can be run for the whole or part of the supply chain. During the deployment optimization all planned stock transfers created by SNP are neglected thereby relaxing the previously made sourcing decisions. As a result, each order can be fulfilled through any of the potential supply sources which has the sufficient amount of the respective products. The confirmed stock transfer orders are read by the TP/VS module to generate a detailed transportation plan.   

 

In this lesson, we show how to run a deployment optimization instance in SNP interactive planning board.

item.title: Analysis of the Optimization Results
Analysis of the Optimization Results Demo
Analysis of the Optimization Results Practice

item.dc:description:
Analysis of the Optimization Results 

The solution of an deployment optimization can be achieved via either the SNP interactive planning board and through the deployment data view, or through the SNP optimizater log data.

Although SNP interactive planning board shows the results of a deployment run, detail analysis of the results is not possible in this environment. Further, to compare the results of different scenarios, you will need to create a planning version for each scenario. However, you can perform several deployment runs in the same planning version but without saving their final results after finishing the optimization process. Then, you can retrieve results of each deployment run in full detail by checking the SNP optimizer log data. Moreover, SNP optimizer log data makes it possible to export different aspects of the deployment results to other applications, e.g. excel for further analysis.

In this lesson, we show how to acheive, analyse and export the results of deployment optimization through SNP optimizer log data.

Deployment Optimization 

In this learning section the initialization, execution and result analysis of deployment optimization are explained. In the first lesson, a short introduction on the deployment cost profile maintenance is presented. In the second lesson, an optimization profile is maintained which explains the potential planning capabilities of deployment optimization in SAP APO. The maintained profiles are employed in the third lesson where an optimization run is performed to handle the potential shortage or inventory surplus situations in the supply chain. Results of the optimization planning are checked in the last lesson.

item.title: In-Depth-Stream: Deployment Heuristics
Deployment Heuristic Profile
item.dc:description:
Deployment Heuristic Profile 

The deployment heuristic profile is used to make deployment heuristic settings. The system considers various distribution rules if the available product quantities exceed or fall below the demand (fair share and push rules). You can set these rules in the SNP deployment profile to be later assigned equally to a group of products in the SNP 2 tab page of the product master. You can also skip defining the deployment profile and specifically define deployment settings for each location-product combination on the SNP2 tab-page of the product master.

In this lesson we show how to create/maintain a deployment heuristic profile and explain its different settings. More specifically, we discuss the following topics:

  • Deployment heuristic strategies
  • Demand consideration

item.title: Deployment Heuristic Run
item.dc:description:
Deployment Heuristic Run

Running deployment heuristic creates a distribution plan by considering all available products at source locations as ATD quantity and then distributing them to cover demands at destination locations.

One important difference between deployment optimization and heuristic run is that the optimization method deploys products such that all supply sources are considered together to generate an optimal solution to the integrated supply chain, while the heuristic method considers each source separately thereby constituting a non-integrated distribution approach.

 

Furthermore, unlike deployment optimizer, deployment heuristic sticks to the sourcing decisions previously made in the SNP plan. Therefore, in order to run it, the system has to be initiliazed by running an SNP heuristic or optimizer to generate SNP stock transfers, or by running supply and demand propagation, or capable-to-match (CTM), to define the sourcing of the orders.   

 

Another difference is that deployment heuristic does not change any deployment order produced during the previous planning runs while deployment optimizer can change or delete the previously generated deployment orders to develop a plan anew.

 

In this lesson, we show how to run a deployment heuristic instance in supply network planning in the background.

Deployment Heuristic

In this learning section the initialization, execution and result analysis of deployment heuristic are explained. In the first lesson, a deployment heuristic profile is maintained which explains the potential planning capabilities of deployment heuristic in SAP APO. The maintained profile is employed in the second lesson where a deployment heuristic run is performed to handle the observed shortage situation in the supply chain. Results of the deployment planning are also briefly checked at the end of this last lesson.

Deployment 

The deployment module generates a detailed confirmed distribution plan for a short horizon. In this respect, it takes the results of the previous planning modules (DP, PP/DS and SNP) as input and transfers its own results to the detailed transportation planning and vehicle scheduling module (TP/VS).

The following figure shows the planning procedure for maintaining the deployment   module:

In the Frutado AG, the deployment planning is performed upon the rolling horizon concept and for the length of 14 days. The objective of deployment planning is to revise the long-term distribution plan provided by the SNP module into a short term plan that best treats the shortage or surplus inventory situations in the supply chain.

A supply chain might observe inventory shortage and surplus conditions due to several reasons such as:

  • Difference between the forecasted demand and the actual customer orders
  • Aggeragation-disaggregation error in production capacity consideration during SNP planning

  • Unexpected resource break-downs 

Deployment planning is explained in the four learning sections. To execute Deployment planning, new master data have to be defined, which will be presented in the first learning section. The concept of rolling horizon based deployment and its respective initializations are explained in the second section. The third learning section, explains deployment optimization and cost profiles, and shows how to run an optimization instance and analyse its results. Profile preparation and execution of a heuristic based deployment is described in the fourth section, and In-Depth Stream section discusses heuristic deployment planning methods.

item.title: Transportation Planning / Vehicle Scheduling
TP/VS Master Data
Means of Transport
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Means of Transport for TP/VS 

Means of transport refers to the types of vehicles used, e.g. different types of trucks or ships. Three different types of trucks are used in the Frutado project.

Creating means of transport is the initial stage in defining TP/VS master data. The created means of transport are later assigned to transportation lanes and are used to classify vehicle resources in the subsequent lessons, see the figure below.

 

This short lesson shows where you can maintain the means of transport for the Frutado supply chain. You learn how to set the average speed, the multiplication factor for the Euclidean distance, the setup time and the working time for the means of transport.

item.title: Vehicle Resources
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Vehicle Resources for TP/VS 

There are two types of transport-relevant resources in APO: transportation resources and vehicle resources. Transportation resources are used in aggregated supply network planning and deployment, while vehicle resources are used in detailed transportation planning (TP/VS).

Vehicle resources are used as planning objects in TP/VS, they show the availability of vehicles used for transportation. A vehicle resource is a concrete means of transport by which the transportation between locations is executed. Each vehicle resource must be assigned to one means of transport.

This lesson shows where you can maintain the vehicle resources and its relevant parameters for the Frutado scenario.

item.title: Shifts for Vehicle Resources
item.dc:description:
Assigning Shifts to Vehicle Resources

In SAP APO it is possible to define daily shifts, for the vehicle resources, for any number of consecutive days (for example a week). Working and break times are defined for each shift, where shift sequences are assigned to time intervals of a capacity variant.

The vehicle resources have already been described in an earlier lesson, however some details were left out. The vehicle resources are weekday-dependent and they are only available for 10 hours on their weekday. Therefore the vehicle resources are actually assigned to shifts to make them only available on their corresponding weekday. In this lesson you will learn how to maintain the shifts for the vehicle resources.

item.title: Loading Resources
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Loading Resources for TP/VS 

Loading resources are used for loading and unloading vehicles whilst taking into account their capacity.

In the Frutado project, it is assumed that three loading resources are available at each distribution center, and one loading resource at each customer location to do the unloading task. A loading resource can serve only one vehicle at a time, which means, the other vehicles, when more than one vehicle need to be loaded/unloaded, must wait until a loading resource is free.

The opening hours of distribution centers and customers are modeled through the settings of their loading resources. The loading resources are acting as constraints in the optimization, since their time windows have to be respected and loading/unloading can only take place during the opening hours.

This lesson shows how to maintain the loading resources for the Frutado project.

item.title: Loading / Unloading Times
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Loading/Unloading Times

In the Frutado scenario both fixed and variable loading and unloading times need to be modeled.

The fixed times occur upon arrival at each location in a delivery run, for example due to time needed for the trucks to maneuver into an optimal unloading position or untie tied down goods if any. The fixed time is modeled such that it is added to the transportation duration. This has already been done for the transportation lanes, for details please refer to the lesson on transportation lanes where the retention period was set to 10 minutes. The reason for doing it in this way is because there is no means of explicitly defining a fixed loading and unloading times for each location reached in the system.

The variable loading/unloading times depends on the weight of the load. Those have not been modeled and in this lesson you will learn how to do that.

item.title: Locations
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Locations for TP/VS  

The precise locations of all customers and distribution centers are needed in order to determine their geographical longitude and latitude. This is important for calculation of transportation distances and durations between the locations.

SAP APO allows for more than ten location types, in the Frutado case only distribution centers, production plants and customer locations are needed. However, as the transportation between plant and DC is not considered, the plant locations are not relevant for the TP/VS module.

This lesson shows where you can maintain the locations and the parameters which are of importance for the TP/VS module, such as the address of the customer, their priority and the available loading resources.

item.title: Transportation Lanes
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Transportation Lanes for TP/VS 

Transportation lanes represent the connections between different locations of the Frutado supply chain. They can be thought of as a road between two locations.

The system can automatically calculate the transportation duration and distance for each lane. Those are calculated based on geographical coordinates, the multiplication factor and the speed of the means of transport.

This lesson explains how to create a transportation lane between two customer locations and to maintain its relevant settings including:

  • The assignment of means of transport to a lane and their respective usage costs.
  • Restricting the products that can be transported on a lane.

item.title: Supply Chain Engineer
item.dc:description:
The Supply Chain Engineer (SCE)

The Supply Chain Engineer is used to create and maintain network models of supply chains. The Supply Chain Engineer screen provides an overview of your model and you can perform the following tasks:

·         Supply chain model maintenance

·         Transportation lane maintenance

·         Execution of queries

 

The purpose of this lesson is to show an overview of the Supply Chain Engineer, because it is a convenient tool for accessing the data of different components of the supply chain, and the TP/VS module accordingly.

Maintaining the TP/VS Master Data 

The master data for TP/VS are basic information that are used consistently throughout the planning and are usually remained unchanged for a long period of time.

This section includes 7 lessons explaining how to maintain the necessary TP/VS master data for the Frutado scenario, those are:

  • Means of Transport
  • Vehicle Resources
  • Shifts for Vehicle Resources
  • Loading Resources
  • Loading/Unloading Times
  • Locations
  • Transportation Lanes

We finish this educational unit by presenting a lesson on how to use the Supply Chain Engineer feature of APO as an alternative method for checking the master data of TP/VS.

item.title: Model Building
Cost Profile
item.dc:description:
Defining a Cost Profile

A cost profile is defined to maintain the common cost terms as well as penalties applied when running a TP/VS optimization model under a planning scenario. In the TP/VS module, some of these costs are service related optimization measures which are hard to quantify. However, they should be defined such that an appropriate trade-off is obtained between different optimization measures of the TP/VS problem.

In the Frutado project, we define the following cost components in the cost profile.

  • Location-relevant costs including earliness, lateness, and non-delivery costs of an order at each location.
  • Transportation-relevant costs including fixed transportation costs per vehicle.
  • Dimension-relevant costs including variable transportation costs per certain units of measurement, e.g. duration and distance.

item.title: Optimization Profile
item.dc:description:
Defining an Optimization Profile

In order to define the scope of the TP/VS for different planning scenarios, different optimization profiles can be maintained to restrict the

  • cost profiles 
  • TP/VS horizons
  • types of orders (ATP categories)
  • locations
  • resources

included in a certain TP/VS planning scenario.

In this lesson you will practice defining an optimization profile through maintaining the respective settings for the Frutado project.

item.title: Pickup / Delivery Windows
item.dc:description:
Defining Windows for Pickup/Delivery

Different constraints are taken into account during the optimization. Generally they can be categorized into hard and soft constraints, or a combination of both. While violation of a hard constraint will result in an infeasible solution, soft constraints might be violated subject to some penalty costs.

In this lesson you will learn how to use hard and soft constraints when defining windows for pickup/delivery.

Note that these pickup/delivery windows, as they are defined in SAP APO, are not related to the opening hours of the customer. This needs to be clarified since in the literature the opening hours of customer are usually referred to as time windows.

item.title: TLB Profile
item.dc:description:
Defining a TLB Profile

Transport Load Builder (TLB) is an optional step that follows the deployment run. The task of TLB is to combine orders that were generated for individual products into a TLB shipment for several products, whilst ensuring that the capacity of the means of transport is utilized as much as possible. However, since no optimization method is used in TLB planning, the optimality of its solution is not guaranteed.

In the Frutado project orders are loaded into euro pallets for transportation. Therefore, TLB is used to bundle the shipments to fit the size of the euro pallets. Besides better vehicle utilization, TLB can be used to combine the deliveries to customers such that only one shipment is performed for each customer per day. Otherwise, the solution of TP/VS might involve several deliveries per day to some customers which might not be practical in real-world applications.

In this lesson you will learn how to create a TLB profile for the Frutado project which will be used later for the TLB-planning.

Model Building

Next to the relevant master data which remain unchanged during a long time-horizon, there are some other TP/VS related parameters and settings which might change more often in the course of time. Since these parameters and settings usually depend on the problem scenario that needs to be modeled, we refer to them as model related settings and explain them for the Frutado project, under the following four categories:

·         Cost Profile

·         Optimization Profile

·         Pickup / Delivery Windows

·         TLB Profile

item.title: TP/VS Planning Run
TLB Planning
item.dc:description:
TLB Planning

Transport Load Builder (TLB) is a short term planning tool which is used to group deployment stock transfers into a TLB shipment. Individual products are combined into a TLB shipment for several products, which is then sent to the customer in question.

In this lesson you will learn how to execute the TLB planning, by building transport loads that are within the parameter limits of the TLB profile which has already been defined in another lesson.  In doing so, the TLB tries to load the shipments as far as possible to the upper parameter limits (1400 kg) defined in the TLB profile.

item.title: TP/VS Optimization
item.dc:description:
TP/VS Optimization

In interactive vehicle scheduling orders are assigned to vehicle resources, either manually or by using the optimizer. As a result planned shipments are generated from the optimization data (that is; orders, deliveries and vehicles).

In this lesson you will learn how to run interactive vehicle scheduling by using the TP/VS optimizer. The shipments are planned on the basis of costs and the optimal delivery sequence for the vehicles as well as transportation dates/times is established. Analyzing the results is also of importance to see if the scheduled shipments meet the expectation of the planner.

item.title: Integration with Deployment
item.dc:description:
Integration with Deployment

The different components of the supply chain have their own objectives which often can be conflicting, and changes in one part of the supply chain can affect the performance of another part. It is therefore a need for integrating and coordinating the different parts of the supply chain.

For the TP/VS module of the Frutado scenario it is relevant to look at the integration between deployment and TP/VS. Transportation planning is a detailed planning method, whereas deployment planning is made on a more aggregated level. This can lead to various capacity related problems, which can be adjusted by using an integration scheme.

As described before, vehicle resources are used in TP/VS planning to transport orders. Vehicle resources are used for detailed planning to map the capacity and availability of vehicles, where the available capacity is not dependent on time. In deployment, transportation resources are used for its aggregated planning where the capacity ensures feasibility of the deployment plan. Transportation resources are bucket resources, meaning that it has a quantity-oriented capacity which can be planned on daily basis. When integrating the two modules, then after running TP/VS planning feedback can be provided back to deployment to revise the weight capacity of the transportation resources.

In this lesson you will learn how to integrate the two planning modules. It will be shown how to calculate an adjustment factor, after running TP/VS, which is used to adjust the capacity of the transportation resources in deployment.

TP/VS Planning Run

In this section you will learn how to perform the optimization with the TP/VS optimizer, which uses both genetic algorithms and evolutionary algorithms in its optimization.

·    The first step is to perform TLB Planning where the orders are combined into shipments.

·    The second step is to perform TP/VS Optimization where the TLB shipments are assigned to vehicles and the routing of the vehicles is determined, whilst taking into account the different constraints defined for the case. Analyzing the results is also an important step, to see if the scheduled shipments meet the expectation of the planner.

·    The third step is to analyze the integration with the Deployment module.

item.title: In-Depth Stream
Scenario with Reduced Shift Lenght
Scenario with Reduced Shift Lenght Demo
Scenario with Reduced Shift Lenght Practice

item.dc:description:
Scenario with Reduced Shift Lenght

In the lesson TP/VS Optimization a planning run was made for the Frutado scenario. The results showed that fixed vehicle cost was the highest cost and that all orders could be delivered with a very small delay cost.

In this lesson we will look into an alternative scenario, where the maximum duration of a trip is set to 8 hours, instead of 10 hours as before.  The reason for this could be that the trade unions have set a new requirement that the drivers are not allowed to work for more than 8 hours. After running the new scenario, the results will be analyzed and compared.

item.title: Transportation Zones
item.dc:description:
Maintaining Transportation Zones

Instead of creating transportation lanes between relevant customers and distribution centers, it is possible to use transportation zones. The advantage of using transportation zones is that the amount of master data that need to be processed can be reduced considerably.

A transportation zone hierarchy is needed where several locations are assigned to. For each transportation zone a reference transportation lane is needed between the source and a reference location in the zone, also an intra-zone lane is needed, that is a lane from the reference location to itself. Then for the locations in the transportation zone all transportation lanes are automatically created between all locations as well as to the source location. This is shown in the figure below:

[Source: www.SAP.com]

In the Frutado scenario, 20 customers have been assigned to each distribution center. Clustering of the customers could be of relevance in a real world situation if for example the drivers have a special knowledge of specific areas.

Using transportation zones is an alternative method that could be used in the Frutado scenario, instead of creating transportation lanes between all customers and its distribution center. This lesson shows where you maintain the transportation zones and how you create a transportation zone hierarchy which the customers are assigned to.

item.title: Returns Planning
item.dc:description:
Returns Planning

In a supply chain it is of importance to consider the recycling and disposal of the products. This is very relevant for the Frutado scenario, where the empty bottles and packaging could be recycled.

In SAP APO it is possible to plan for return deliveries, for example if the products are defected and need to be sent back to the supplier. This could also include return shipments of empties,like in the Frutado scenario where the customers could send their empty bottles back to the DC.

In SAP APO, planning returns deliveries corresponds to planning of sales orders, where the system treats returns like outbound deliveries although they are in fact inbound deliveries. The aim of the planning in TP/VS is to ship the returns back to the DC, on the return leg of the route. Therefore a route is planned for each vehicle, where orders for different customers are delivered and the empty bottles are also shipped back to the DC. In this way forward and return logistics are integrated.

In this lesson you will learn how to implement returns planning on a small and simplified example, including one DC and five customers in a one day scenario.

item.title: TLB in Background
item.dc:description:
TLB in Background

In the lesson TLB Planning, it was shown how to run the TLB planning for one customer. Instead of making a special planning run for all customers it is also possible to run the TLB as a background job.

In this lesson you will learn how to run TLB in the Background for all 60 customers in the Frutado scenario.

In-Depth Stream for TP/VS

After having modeled and analyzed the basic elements of the Transportation Planning

and Vehicle Scheduling for the Frutado scenario, this section presents

further extensions and more advanced settings.

Transportation Planning / Vehicle Scheduling (TP/VS)

The objective of transportation planning is to group confirmed deliveries into scheduled shipments whilst taking into account certain constraints such as:

  • Capacity restriction of vehicles
  • Vehicle availabilty
  • Calendars of the customers for loading/unloading 
  • Due dates
  • Products and/or locations incompatibilities

The position of the TP/VS module and its data exchange with the other planning modules of SAP APO is illustrated in the figure below.

The detailed processes of the TP/VS module are presented through 4 learning sections with focusing on the problem settings of the Frutado project. The first section is dedicated to explaining the maintenance of the relevant master data for TP/VS. Details on building the optimization model, including creation of cost profiles, constraints and optimization methods are presented in the second section. In the third section, lessons are aimed to show how the planning should be run and how the results should be analyzed. In order to cover the other important features of the TP/VS module, which are not in the scope of the Frutado project, the In-depth stream section is presented in section 4 as a group of supplementary TP/VS lessons.

Tutorial 

Welcome to the tutorial part of the DVD.

This part of the DVD guides you through the different planning modules of the SAP APO. The structure for every module is the same and consists of three so-called streams. The first stream – the demo stream – presents all the activities which are necessary to fulfill the planning task of the Frutado AG. This stream is the basis of the two following streams. The second stream – the practice stream – allows knowledge gained in the first stream to be tested. A deeper insight into each module is given by the last stream – the in-depth stream. This stream shows additional features of the different modules that were not necessarily needed to complete the planning of the Frutado AG. After finishing all streams the planning of the Frutado AG is completed.

In order to begin your lessons simply click on the module of your choice. It is recommended to begin with the Demand Planning Module.
Each module is introduced and then split into different projects which will guide you through the complete planning process. The in-depth stream is an additional group of the according module and should be attended to after surveying the demo stream. To start a demo select a lesson and click on the demo icon at the top right of your screen. In order to use the practice stream click on the practice icon next to the demo icon. Proceed exactly as in the demo stream.

organization.dc:description:
Welcome to the Frutado AG

This DVD does not only describe Supply Chain Management in theory but it also presents a more practical approach.
With the help of a fictitious company – the Frutado Company – certain planning modules of the SAP Advanced Planner and Optimizer are explained. The goal of this DVD is to present the various models and the possibilities of the SAP APO.

The first chapter deals with the Frutado AG as a company. After a general introduction, all relevant data for the SAP APO is described and the planning concept is presented. The next chapter deals with the fundamentals and the structure of Advanced Planning Systems going into greater detail with the SAP APO. The last part of the DVD consists of a Tutorial which guides you through the different planning modules of the SAP APO.

For detailed information concerning supply chain management and advanced planning systems refer to “Supply Chain Management and Advanced Planning” edited by Hartmut Stadtler and Christopher Kilger.
